questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with severe pain in the buttocks extending down the back of the right leg. MRI revealed inflammation of the piriformis muscle. Entrapment of which of the following nerves is likely to cause the given condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of piriformis syndrome, which occurs due to the entrapment of the sciatic nerve.

It is triggered by sitting for a long time or running, climbing stairs, or applying firm pressure directly over the piriformis muscle. Early signs include pain, tingling, or numbness in the buttocks. Later it may lead to severe pain extending down the length of the sciatic nerve.

questions.text: A junior resident, during his first emergency room duty, comes across a patient with difficulty in breathing. Since he was not confident to do endotracheal intubation, he tries to secure the airway with the following device. All of the following are the advantages of using this device when compared with tracheal intubation, except that _____.

choices.text: It does not require neck mobility.
It is associated with decreased risk of gastrointestinal aspiration.
It does not require muscle relaxation.
There is no risk of endobronchial intubation.

questions.solution:
This given image is of a laryngeal mask airway (LMA). All of the options are the advantages of using this device when compared with tracheal intubation except that it is associated with a decreased risk of gastrointestinal aspiration. There is an increased risk of gastrointestinal aspiration when compared with tracheal intubation.

The laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is a supraglottic airway device that sits in the hypopharynx and partially protects the larynx from pharyngeal secretions, but not gastric regurgitation.

Advantages and disadvantages of the laryngeal mask airway compared with tracheal intubation: 

Advantages:

  • Less invasive
  • Very useful in difficult intubations
  • Less tooth and laryngeal trauma
  • Does not require muscle relaxation
  • Does not require neck mobility 
  • No risk of esophageal or endobronchial intubation

Disadvantages:

  • Increased risk of gastrointestinal aspiration
  • Less safe in prone or jack-knife positions
  • Less secure airway
  • Greater risk of gas leak and pollution
  • Can cause gastric distention

questions.text: Which is the most commonly used confirmatory test for HIV?
questions.solution:
The most commonly used confirmatory test for HIV is the Western blot. 

Western blot demonstrating antibodies to products of all three of the major genes of HIV (gag, pol, and env) is conclusive evidence of infection with HIV. It is considered positive if it shows antibodies against at least two of the following gene products: p24, gp41, gp120/ 160. 

Other options:

Option A: ELISA (Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay) is the most commonly used screening test for HIV. It is a simple, relatively inexpensive screening test for HIV.

Option C: DNA PCR (Polymerase chain reaction) is a specific test for the detection of HIV infection where proviral DNA from the peripheral lymphocytes of the patient's samples is amplified and identified. When performed correctly, this test has a high specificity and sensitivity.

Option D: p24 which is the core antigen of the virus is the earliest to occur and is employed for early diagnosis. A p24 antigen capture assay where anti-p24 antibodies bound with p24 is used with ELISA to demonstrate HIV. This test is useful in the following scenarios - 

  • Newly exposed to the risk of infection
  • People who test negative for the antibody
  • The terminal phase of infection

questions.text: Identify the condition based on the image given below.
questions.solution:
The above image with fish-like scales is suggestive of ichthyosis. It is a family of genetic disorders characterized by the presence of excessive amounts of dry thickened scaly skin.  

The commonest form of ichthyosis vulgaris is due to a genetic defect in the gene FLG coding for filaggrin protein. Ichthyosis usually develops during the first months of life. 

The patients present with light grey scales mainly on the extensor surfaces of the extremities and the trunk. The scaling may disappear or reduce in the summer and when there is increased humidity. They usually have accentuated palmar creases.

The condition is managed with ointments like glycerol-containing creams that hydrate the stratum corneum.

Other options:

Option A: Acrodermatitis enteropathica is caused by a defect in the absorption of zinc. It presents as eczematous plaques that are usually periorificial on the face or the anogenital area. They may become vesicular, bullous, pustular, or erosive with crusting at the edges. It is shown below.

 

Option C: Atopic dermatitis in children classically have patches and plaques on antecubital and popliteal fossae. Adults have chronic lichenified lesions mainly on the hands. It is associated with itching. It is shown below.

Option D: Kaposi sarcoma: Skin lesions of Kaposi sarcoma are dark blue to purple and may partially blanch when swollen. They are usually multifocal and may fuse to form plaques and tumors. It is seen below.

Related Pearl: Types of scales associated with dermatological conditions

Types of Scales and Associated Diseases

Type of Scale

Associated Disease

Collarette scale

It is a fine, peripherally attached, and centrally detached scale at the edge of an inflammatory lesion. It is seen in pityriasis rosea.

Fish-like scales

They are seen in ichthyosis vulgaris (ichthyos - fish). Ichthyotic scales are large and polygonal.

Silvery scales

They are characteristic of processes involving parakeratosis, especially psoriasis. The silvery color is due to the reflection of light at several air–keratin interfaces.

Mica-like scales

They are seen in Pityriasis lichenoides. The lesions are polymorphic with some showing hemorrhagic crusting and adherent scales.

Yellow / greasy scales

Seborrheic dermatitis

Leaf-like scales

Pemphigus foliaceous

Powdery, branny, fine scales

Pityriasis versicolor

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient came with complaints of progressive hearing loss. On thorough workup, it was diagnosed to be a clean case of otosclerosis. What would be the tympanic membrane finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
In otosclerosis, the tympanic membrane is normal unless there is another co-existing pathology.

Otosclerosis is a primary disease of the bony labyrinth where one or more foci of irregularly spongy bone replace part of the normal bony otic capsule. Patients present with painless and progressive hearing loss, often the bilateral conductive type. They may hear better in noisy than in quiet environments (paracusis willisii).

The tympanic membrane is normal and mobile. A reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign). This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. Eustachian tube function is normal.

Pure tone audiometry shows a loss of air conduction, more for lower frequencies. Bone conduction is normal. In some cases, there may be a dip in the bone conduction curve. It is different at different frequencies but greatest at 2000 Hz and is called Carhart’s notch. It is shown in the image below.

 

Surgical management includes stapedectomy and stapedotomy with the placement of a prosthesis.

The types of stapedial otosclerosis are:

  • Anterior focus
  • Posterior focus
  • Circumferential
  • Biscuit type (thick plate)
  • Obliterative

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

 

Related Pearl: Meniere’s disease vs. Otosclerosis

Meniere’s Disease

Otosclerosis

Middle age (M>F)

Middle age (F>>M)

Unilateral

Bilateral

Sensory neural hearing loss

Conductive Hearing loss

Cochlear pathology (endolymphatic system)

Middle ear pathology (stapes footplate)

questions.text: Which of the following is not an orphan drug?
questions.solution:
Acetaminophen is not an orphan drug. It is an essential drug.

Orphan drugs are drugs for rare diseases.

Orphan drugs are for the treatment or prevention of rare diseases with little commercial value for pharmaceutical companies. Therefore, special incentives are given by the government for the pharmaceutical companies for the development and marketing of orphan drugs.

Few examples of orphan drugs:

  • Miltefosine
  • Sodium nitrite
  • Succimer
  • Rifabutin
  • Liposomal amphotericin B
  • Fomepizole

questions.text: A female child is being evaluated for primary amenorrhea and short stature. An ultrasound was done, and it showed a small uterus and streak ovaries. Which of the following cardiac anomaly is most likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of primary amenorrhea and short stature along with streak ovaries in the ultrasound is suggestive of Turner syndrome. It is frequently associated with left-sided cardiovascular anomalies like bicuspid aortic valves.

Turner syndrome occurs due to complete or partial monosomy of X-chromosomes. It produces hypogonadism in phenotypic females.

Clinical findings include webbing of the neck, protruding ears, and lymphedema of the hands and feet, short stature. The gonads are streaks of fibrous tissue, known as gonadal dysgenesis. There is primary amenorrhea and a lack of secondary sex characteristics. Congenital heart anomalies and structural renal anomalies are common.

Cardiac anomalies in Turner syndrome: Common defects are bicuspid aortic valves, coarctation of the aorta, aortic stenosis, and mitral valve prolapse. Cardiovascular abnormalities are the most important cause of mortality.

Related Pearl: Disorders of Sexual Development

Disorder

Complete androgen insensitivity

Mullerian agenesis

Turner syndrome

Complete XY dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome)

Cause

X-linked mutation of androgen receptor

Hypoplastic or absent Mullerian ductal system

Also called Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome

Complete or partial absence of one X chromosome

SRY gene mutation on the Y chromosome

Reproductive organs

Absent uterus and upper vagina, cryptorchid testis

Absent or rudimentary uterus and upper vagina, normal ovaries

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Breast

Yes

Yes

Variable

No

Axillary/Pubic hair

Minimal to absent

Normal

Normal

Minimal to absent

Karyotype

46 XY

46 XX

45 XO or 

45 X mosaicism

46 XY

 

Note: 

Turner's syndrome have different chromosomal anomalies:

  • 45 XO which is seen in 40-50% patients 
  • 45 X mosaicism (eg, 45,X/46,XX or 45,X/47,XXX, or 45,X mosaics with the X chromosome anomalies)

questions.text: A 52-year-old diabetic male patient was found to have a bilateral loss of peripheral visual fields. On tonometry, intraocular pressure was raised. Fundoscopy showed cupping and pallor of the optic disc. Iridocorneal angle was normal on gonioscopy. He is started on a topical drug that reduces the intraocular pressure by increasing the uveoscleral flow. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
The topical drug started that reduces intraocular pressure by increasing the uveoscleral flow is latanoprost, a prostaglandin analog. It is used in the treatment of open-angle glaucoma. 

This patient's findings of peripheral vision loss, increased intraocular pressure (IOP) with optic disc cupping, and a normal iridocorneal angle is suggestive of open-angle glaucoma.

Topical prostaglandins like latanoprost, travoprost, bimatoprost, and tafluprost are now used as first-line agents to lower IOP. The major mechanism of action is by enhancing the uveoscleral outflow though they also increase trabecular outflow.

The most common ocular side effects are conjunctival hyperemia, eyelash thickening, iris hyperpigmentation, and loss of periorbital fat. These drugs are administered once every day at bedtime and are used with caution in inflamed eyes.

The systemic side effects are uncommon and include occasional headaches, malaise, myalgia, skin rash, and mild upper respiratory infections. Latanoprost is preferred as the first-line due to fewer ocular side effects.

Other options:

Option A: Dorzolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. It reduces IOP by decreasing aqueous production. 

Option C: Mannitol is an osmotic agent, which lowers IOP by creating an osmotic gradient so that water is pulled from the vitreous into the blood vessels. It is used as a short-term treatment to reduce IOP in acute angle-closure glaucoma or prior to intraocular surgery.

Option D: Pilocarpine is a miotic that acts as a cholinergic agonist. In angle-closure glaucoma, cholinergic agents open the angle by contraction of the sphincter pupillae, pulling the iris away from the trabecula.

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor (Netarsudil)

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text:
A 20-year-old medical student presented with 6 months of generalized body ache, which increases with stress and does not respond to NSAIDs. She also complains of sleep disturbances and low mood. On examination, there is increased pain sensitivity and tender bony prominences. Investigations are given below. The most probable diagnosis is:
  • Routine blood and urine- normal
  • ESR- normal
  • anti-CCP- normal
  • Viral markers-  IgG against HbsAg +
  • Chest and pelvic X-ray- normal
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for the given clinical scenario is fibromyalgia.

The examination findings of tender bony prominences and increased pain sensitivity with associated low mood favour the diagnosis of fibromyalgia. Flaring up symptoms during stress and not having pain relief with NSAIDs also support the diagnosis of fibromyalgia.

Fibromyalgia is a diagnosis of exclusion. Other possible conditions like anemia, TB, infections like UTI, rheumatoid arthritis, etc. have to be excluded.

Fibromyalgia is characterized by chronic musculoskeletal pain and tenderness. It is more common in females. Patients with fibromyalgia have an increased prevalence of other syndromes associated with pain and fatigue, including chronic fatigue syndrome, chronic headaches, irritable bowel syndrome, interstitial cystitis/painful bladder syndrome, and other pelvic pain syndromes.

Treatment strategies include physical conditioning, strength training, exercise programs, and cognitive-behavioral strategies

Other options: 

Option A: Normal levels of ESR and anti-CCP antibodies (Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide) exclude the diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis.

Option B: Ankylosing spondylitis improves with exercise, unlike this case. Moreover, it might show sacroiliitis on the pelvic radiographs and responds well to NSAIDs. 

Option C: Hepatitis B infection is included in the differential diagnosis of fibromyalgia but the presence of IgG against HbsAg points towards vaccination rather than active infection which would show IgM antibodies against various antigens of Hep B.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with ischemic heart disease and atrial fibrillation presents with sudden, severe, generalized abdominal pain and multiple episodes of vomiting. On examination, the pulse rate is 118 bpm, rhythm is irregularly irregular, and BP is 92/58 mm Hg. The abdomen appears soft, and non-distended, and bowel sounds are absent. Which of the following is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute mesenteric ischemia. For an acute arterial occlusive disease, the gold standard for diagnosis is angiography and that for management is laparotomy.

An embolus is the most common cause of acute mesenteric ischemia. Risk factors for acute mesenteric ischemia/embolus in the given clinical scenario are as follows:

  • Presence of an irregularly irregular pulse is suggestive of atrial fibrillation. 
  • Previous history of ischemic heart disease

The most important clue to an early diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia is the sudden onset of severe abdominal pain in a patient with atrial fibrillation or atherosclerosis. The pain is typically in the central abdomen and out of proportion to the physical findings. Associated symptoms can include nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. With the onset of bowel infarction, abdominal distension, peritonitis, and passage of bloody stools occur.

The gold standard for the diagnosis of an acute arterial occlusive disease is angiography and that for management is laparotomy. The goal of operative exploration is to resect the compromised bowel and restore blood supply via embolectomy.

Note:

A pulsatile abdominal mass is seen in the case of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Acute pain and hypotension occur with rupture of the aneurysm, which requires an emergency operation.

Acute severe pancreatitis and peptic ulcer perforation have no association with atrial fibrillation. They usually present with pain over the upper abdomen, associated with guarding and rigidity on examination.

questions.text: Identify the instrument given below. Which of the following structures is not cut during the procedure most commonly carried out by this instrument?

choices.text: Transverse perineal branches of pudendal  nerves

questions.solution:
The instrument in the given image is an episiotomy scissors. The obturator muscle is not cut during mediolateral episiotomy which is the most commonly done procedure using this instrument.

A surgically planned incision on the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labour is called an episiotomy. In mediolateral episiotomy, the incision is made downwards and outwards from the midpoint of the fourchette either to the right or to the left.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles
  • Bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering these muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

The other types of episiotomy include median, lateral, and J shaped episiotomy.

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: A 7-month-old child with acute diarrhea is being treated with oral rehydration solution (ORS).  Which of the following is correct regarding zinc supplementation in this child?
questions.solution:
A 7-month-old child being treated for acute diarrhea should be supplemented with oral zinc at 20 mg/day for 10-14 days.

Zinc administration for diarrhea management can significantly reduce mortality and hospital admission. In addition, it improves diarrhea recovery rates and reduces the inappropriate use of antimicrobials.

Zinc supplementation is usually done for 10 to 14 days. The dosage is age-dependent as follows:

Age <6 months: 10 mg/day

Age >6 months:  20 mg/day

Related Pearl: Treatment of dehydration based on severity

Plan A: For no dehydration or minimal dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool.

Age Amount 
<2 years 50–100 mL
2-10 years 100–200 mL
>10 years As much fluid as they want

Plan B: For moderate dehydration.

The amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given is 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75).

Plan C: Severe dehydration

Age First, give 30 mL/kg in Followed by 70 mL/kg in Total 100 mL/kg in
Infants (under 12 months) 1 hr 5 hrs  6 hrs
Older 30 min 2½ hrs  3 hrs

Note: Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as intravenous fluids.

Related Pearl: Comparison between low-osmolar oral rehydration solution and ReSoMal

Composition Low-osmolar ORS (mmol/L) ReSoMal (mmol/L)
Glucose  75 125
Sodium  75  45
Potassium  20  40
Chloride  65  70
Citrate  10  7
Magnesium  ---  3
Zinc  --- 0.3
Copper  --- 0.045
Osmolarity (mOsmol/L) 245 300

Related Pearl: Symptoms associated with different levels of dehydration

Symptoms No or minimal dehydration Mild to moderate dehydration Severe dehydration
Loss of body weight <3% 3–9% >9%
Mental status Well; alert Fatigued or irritable Lethargic or unconscious
Thirst Drinks normally Thirsty; eager to drink Drinks poorly
Heart rate Normal Normal to increased Tachycardia
Quality of pulse Normal Normal to decreased Weak, thready or impalpable
Skin turgor test Instant recoil Recoil in <2 sec Recoil in >2 sec
Capillary refill Normal Prolonged Prolonged

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presented with progressive swelling and pain in his right lower limb. X-ray shows findings seen in the image below and a CT scan of the chest reveals osteoblastic metastases. What is the most common location of this underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of bone swelling and pain with imaging revealing Codman's triangle is suggestive of osteosarcoma. The most common location of this disease is the distal femoral metaphysis.

Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor. It is characterized by osteoid production by malignant cells. It has a bimodal age distribution, occurring in adolescence (10–14 years) and again in the 7th decade of life.

Patients present with localized pain and a soft tissue mass. Most times metastasis is already present at diagnosis such as in this patient. Night pain may be seen in some patients.

Diagnosis involves an X-ray initially. The X-ray shows the destruction of the normal trabecular bone pattern, indistinct margins, and no endosteal bone response. Periosteal new bone formation presents as the formation of Codman's triangle. It refers to the part where new bone forms in response to periosteal elevation. A sunburst pattern may be seen and it occurs when the periosteum does not have time to lay down a new layer. Instead, the Sharpey’s fibers stretch perpendicular to the periosteum causing this pattern.

MRI is the best imaging modality to measure the extent of the spread of the tumor into the bone and adjacent structures. A bone scan is used to detect skeletal metastases, and a CT of the chest is done to search for lung metastases. This is because the lungs are the most common site of metastases. 

 

Related Pearl: Summary of Bone Tumors

Bone tumor Most common site Age
Simple bone cyst Proximal Humeral Metaphysis <20years
Enchondroma

Hand bones

(Metaphysis of small bones of hand)

4th & 5th

Decade

Osteochondroma

(Exostosis)

 Distal Femoral Metaphysis <18years
Osteoid osteoma Diaphysis of Femur

2nd & 3rd

decade
Osteoblastoma Posterior column of vertebra

2nd & 3rd

decade

Osteoclastoma (GCT)

 Distal femoral epiphysis

2nd -4th

Decade
Aneurysmal Bone Cyst Long bone Metaphysis <18years
Osteosarcoma Distal Femoral Metaphysis

BIMODAL

Primary- 2nd Decade Secondary-6th and 7th Decade
Ewings sarcoma Diaphysis of Femur 5-25 years
Chondrosarcoma Any site in the bone - mc in proximal femur 3rd-5th decade
Clear cell chondrosarcoma Proximal femoral epiphysis  3rd-5th decade
Adamantinoma Diaphysis of Tibia  20-40 years
 Fibrous dysplasia  The upper end of femur > tibia  1st to 3rd decade
 Chordoma  Sacrum  5th to 7th decade
Multiple myeloma Vertebrae 5th to 7th decade

questions.text: During a psychiatric assessment, a patient was shown a series of pictures to assess his personality. One of those pictures is given below. Identify the personality test.
questions.solution:
The image shows one of the cards from the thematic apperception test (TAT). It is a projective personality test intended to evaluate a person's personality through their responses to ambiguous pictures.

The TAT consists of a series of pictures that depict individuals of both sexes and of different age groups involved in different activities. The stories that the patient makes up concerning the pictures reflect the patient's own needs, thoughts, feelings, stresses, wishes, and views of the future. A sample picture from the TAT series of cards is shown below.

Other options:

Option A: The Rorschach test is a projective personality test that contains a series of symmetric inkblot cards. One of such cards is shown below. The examiner records the patient's description of these inkblots verbatim, which helps in the assessment of his/her personality.

Option C: Holtzman inkblot technique is a projective personality test that contains two parallel forms of inkblot cards. This test is not widely used.

Option D: Make a picture story (MAPS) is similar to the thematic apperception test. However, the stimuli can be manipulated by the patient, and is not widely used.

Related Pearl: Personality tests

Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (MMPI-2)

Uses Characteristics

The most commonly used objective personality test.

Useful for primary care physicians because no training is required for administration and scoring 

Evaluating the attitude of the patient toward taking the test

Objective test

Patients answer 567 true(T) or false(F) questions about themselves.

Clinical scales include depression, paranoia, schizophrenia, and hypochondriasis.

Validity scales identify trying to look ill (faking bad or malingering) or trying to look well (faking good) 

 

Rorschach Test

Uses Characteristics

The most commonly used projective personality test. 

Used to identify thought disorders and defense mechanisms

Projective test 

Patients are asked to interpret 10 bilaterally symmetrical inkblot designs (e.g., Describe what you see in this figure)

 

 

Thematic Apperception Test (TAT)

Uses Characteristics

Stories are used to evaluate unconscious emotions and conflicts

Projective test

Patients are asked to create a verbal scenario based on 20 drawings depicting ambiguous situations (e.g., Using the picture, make up a story that has a beginning, a middle, and an end)

The image given below is the first card, drawn by Christiana D. Morgan. It is a recreation of a photograph taken by Samuel Lumiere of violinist, Yehudi Menuhin, in 1928.

 

Sentence Completion Test

Uses Characteristics
Used to identify worries and problems using verbal associations

Projective test

Patients complete sentences started by the examiner

questions.text: A patient presented with a 3-week history of dry cough and dyspnea on exertion. Gallium-67 nuclear scan of this patient showed the lambda sign. This sign involves all the following structures except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the lambda sign on the gallium-67 scan suggest that the patient has sarcoidosis. Gallium-67 scan does not involve the left paratracheal nodes.

The image given below shows the panda sign (A) and the lambda sign (B) on the gallium-67 scan seen in sarcoidosis.

The lambda sign seen on gallium-67 scans is the gallium equivalent of the 1-2-3 sign or Pawnbrokers sign seen in the setting of thoracic sarcoidosis. It involves:

  • Right paratracheal nodes
  • Right hilar nodes
  • Left hilar nodes

1-2-3 sign or Pawnbrokers sign is a lymph node enlargement pattern on chest X-rays. It is also known as the Garland triad and involves the same three groups of lymph nodes. It is shown below.

The chest radiograph is the preferred tool used to stage sarcoidosis.

Stage 1 Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy (usually symmetrical); right paratracheal nodes often enlarged
Stage 2  Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and parenchymal infiltrates
Stage 3 Parenchymal infiltrates without bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy
Stage 4  Pulmonary fibrosis

questions.text: A pregnant woman's blood investigations reveal iron deficiency anemia. She is prescribed nutritional supplements and albendazole under the Anemia Mukt Bharat program. Albendazole would be given to her preferably during:
questions.solution:
Under the Anemia Mukt Bharat program, deworming treatment for pregnant women is provided preferably during the second trimester.

The table reiterates the deworming dose and regime to be followed according to the Anemia Mukt Bharat program:

Age group Deworming

Children:
6-59 months of age

 A biannual dose of 400 mg Albendazole
(½ tablet for children 12-24 months and 1 tablet for children 24-59 months).
Children:
5-9 years of age		 Biannual dose of 400 mg Albendazole (1 tablet).
School-going adolescents and
Out-of-school adolescent girls-
10-19 years of age		 Biannual dose of 400 mg Albendazole (1 tablet).
Women of reproductive age
(non-pregnant, non-lactating)-
20-49 years of age		 Biannual dose of 400 mg Albendazole (1 tablet).
Pregnant women and
Lactating mothers (0-6 months)		 One dose of 400 mg Albendazole (1 tablet), after the first trimester, preferably during the second trimester

 

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat 2018 scheme, giving IFA to children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women, irrespective of their anemia status, is a key intervention.

 Weekly   Red
Pregnant Women and Lactating Mothers
of 0-6 months child

 

1 iron and folic acid tablet starting from the fourth month of pregnancy is continued throughout pregnancy (minimum 180 days). It should also be continued for 180 days post-partum.

60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid,

Sugar-coated and red color

 Daily  Red 

Note 1: Prophylaxis with iron should be withheld in case of acute illness (fever, diarrhea, pneumonia, etc.) and in a known case of thalassemia major/ history of repeated blood transfusion. In cases of children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), IFA supplementation should be continued as per the SAM management protocol.

Note 2: All women in the reproductive age group in the pre-conception period and up to the first trimester of the pregnancy are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets, daily, to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

questions.text: A 10-month-old male baby presents with vomiting, lethargy, and severe jaundice when weaning was started with fruit juice. Which of the following can give a positive reaction in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The appearance of the above clinical features after the initiation of fruit juice (rich in fructose) suggests a disorder of fructose metabolism. Seliwanoff's reagent gives a positive reaction in this condition.

Hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI) is due to a deficiency of the enzyme aldolase B. It is an autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism. Defective aldolase B causes the accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate. This will inhibit glycogen phosphorylase and cause glycogen accumulation in the liver and associated hypoglycemia.

Symptoms occur when sucrose (fructose+glucose) is introduced into the diet of infants, usually around 6 months of age. Patients will present with vomiting, loss of appetite, and failure to thrive. Hepatomegaly and jaundice may occur. If liver damage progresses, death will occur. 

Fructose is also excreted in the urine. This gives a positive reducing sugar test (Benedict's test), a positive test for furfural derivatives, and specifically a positive Seliwanoff's test (for fructose). Withdrawal of fructose from the diet will immediately relieve the symptoms

Seliwanoff's test will distinguish glucose and fructose. The reagent is resorcinol in HCl. 3 ml of the reagent and 0.5 ml of urine are heated for 30 seconds up to a boiling point. A red color indicates the presence of fructose.

Benedict's test detects the excretion of reducing substances in the urine. About 0.5 ml of urine is boiled with 5 ml of Benedict's reagent for 2 minutes. The formation of a precipitate is observed on cooling. The test is semi-quantitative and the color of the precipitate roughly parallels the concentration of reducing sugar. The blue color indicates the absence of sugar in the urine. The green precipitate means 0.5%, yellow (1%), orange (1.5%) and red indicates 2% or more sugar (1% means 1 g per 100 ml). 

Furfural test: Monosaccharides when treated with concentrated sulphuric acid undergo dehydration with the removal of 3 molecules of water. Hexoses give hydroxymethylfurfural and pentoses give furfural. The furfural derivative can condense with phenolic compounds to give colored products. This forms the basis of the Molisch test. It is a general test for carbohydrates. 

The image summarizes the metabolic pathways involved in the metabolism of fructose:

questions.text: Which of the following events is not likely to be seen in a normal ECG?
questions.solution:
Atrial repolarization is not likely to be seen on a normal ECG.

Atrial repolarization occurs during ventricular depolarization. However, the voltage of the atrial repolarization is very low and is masked by the QRS complex representing ventricular depolarization. 

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

Ventricular repolarization

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential

questions.text: A patient who presented with acute confusion and vomiting was diagnosed to have SIADH. This condition can be best treated by which of the following methods?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of acute symptomatic SIADH and this condition is best treated by the infusion of hypertonic (3%) saline. This mode of treatment also helps in the correction of sodium deficiency that is partly responsible for hyponatremia.

The other form of treatment is to help reduce the concentration of body water by giving an AVP receptor-2 antagonist, conivaptan. Conivaptan blocks the antidiuretic effect of AVP and increases urine output.

DDAVP is a synthetic analog of AVP and should not be used as it will further increase water retention.

questions.text: During an autopsy, you notice that the body is in a pugilistic attitude. The cause behind this is?
questions.solution:
Pugilistic attitude (boxing, fencing, or defense attitude ): The posture of a body which has been exposed to high amount of heat e.g. in case of burns.

This occurs due to the coagulation of the muscle proteins and dehydration. It is more marked in the flexors than extensors.

  • The legs are flexed at the hips and knees,
  • The arms are flexed at the elbows and wrists
  • Fingers are clawed
  • Head slightly extended
  • Marked opisthotonus
